context: Label for establishmentMeans controlled concept scheme http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e
text: establishmentMeans controlled concept scheme

context: Definition for establishmentMeans controlled concept scheme http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e
text: A SKOS Concept Scheme to be used as a controlled vocabulary for the Darwin Core terms dwc:establishmentMeans and dwciri:establishmentMeans
native (indigenous)
A taxon occurring within its natural range.
What is considered native to an area varies with the biogeographic history of an area and the local interpretation of what is a "natural range".
native: reintroduced
A taxon re-established by direct introduction by humans into an area that was once part of its natural range, but from where it had become extinct.
Where a taxon has become extirpated from an area where it had naturally occurred it may be returned to that area deliberately with the intention of re-establishing it.

context: Label for introduced (alien, exotic, non-native, nonindigenous) http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e003
text: introduced (alien, exotic, non-native, nonindigenous)

context: Definition for introduced (alien, exotic, non-native, nonindigenous) http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e003
text: Establishment of a taxon by human agency into an area that is not part of its natural range.

context: Notes for introduced (alien, exotic, non-native, nonindigenous) http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e003
text: Organisms can be introduced to novel areas and habitats by human activity, either on purpose or by accident. Humans can also inadvertently create corridors that break down natural barriers to dispersal and allow organisms to spread beyond their natural range.

context: Label for introduced: assisted colonisation http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e004
text: introduced: assisted colonisation

context: Definition for introduced: assisted colonisation http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e004
text: Establishment of a taxon specifically with the intention of creating a self-sustaining wild population in an area that is not part of the taxon's natural range.

context: Notes for introduced: assisted colonisation http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/e004
text: In the event of environmental change and habitat destruction a conservation option is to introduce a taxon into an area it did not naturally occur.
vagrant (casual)
The temporary occurrence of a taxon far outside its natural or migratory range.
Natural events and human activity can disperse organisms unpredictably into places where they may stay or survive for a period.
uncertain (unknown, cryptogenic)
The origin of the occurrence of the taxon in an area is obscure.
When there is a lack of fossil or historical evidence for the occurrence of a taxon in an area it can be impossible to know if the taxon is new to the area or native.
native: endemic
A taxon with a natural distribution restricted to a single geographical area.

The term endemic is a subcategory of native and relates to geography, such as "areas of endemism", bioregions, and sometimes administrative boundaries. While a native taxon can naturally occur in several geographical areas an endemic taxon only occurs in one. In Darwin Core terms this would mean, "A dwc:Organism referred to is recognized as a member of a dwc:Taxon endemic to the dcterms:Location at the time of the dwc:Occurrence."
